title: Tuesday, 3rd January, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:03 am
BE11:03am

Hello, good morning, welcome, hi.

BE11:03am

And the first dose of tech issues. Murph's locked out.

BE11:03am

No readers either, unsurprisingly.

11:03 am
PM11:03am

I'm in now

PM11:04am

But we need to get this sorted, pronto

PM11:04am

Hi there Rabble

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Bear with us. I for one am a tad rusty

PM11:04am

Shall I get an image up Bryce?

BE11:04am

Please!

11:05 am
PM11:05am

PM11:05am

PM11:05am

11:05 am
PM11:05am

PM11:05am

PM11:06am

11:06 am

Meanwhile, in the UK...

PM11:07am

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Well, i didn't

PM11:07am

BE11:08am

Well, yes. We need to make the usual dull points about the FTSE's record high .......

11:08 am
BE11:08am

.... first, it's been on no volume. The back week of 2016 was no different from the back week of any other year in that respect.

BE11:09am

Second, there's the fact that the FTSE 100 has underperformed pretty much every other index on earth last year.

PM11:09am

This second point is not widely known

11:09 am
BE11:09am

It's ignored because our media are parochial.

BE11:10am

Third, there's that dollar thing we've been banging on abotu here for six months or so.

PM11:10am

hmm

11:10 am
BE11:10am

For the sake of convenience, here's the FTSE 100 USD index.

http://markets.ft....mary?s=UKXUSD+:FSI

PM11:11am

http://markets.ft....mary?s=UKXUSD+:FSI

11:12 am
BE11:13am

Arguably.

BE11:13am

Anyway, that's the 2016 classics covered. We should perhaps move on to something more fresh.

undefined
11:13 am
PM11:14am

So what's fresh for the New Year

PM11:14am

Retailers under pressure

PM11:14am

Banks not

11:14 am
PM11:14am

Oil moves already priced in

BE11:14am

The usual place to start is retail. No warnings yet.

PM11:15am

yet

11:15 am
BE11:15am

Next is usually fast enough to add up the numbers before the tinsel's come down.

BE11:16am

What we have instead, or did on the 31st I think, was Deutsche selling the sector.

PM11:16am

It's dated Jan 1

11:16 am
PM11:16am

Warwick Okines and team, working through the new year...

BE11:17am

Yup, someone had an exciting Hogmanay I guess. Uploading retail a 99 page PDF about consumer spending to BlueMatrix or whatever.

BE11:17am

Here's the upshot.

11:17 am
BE11:17am

2017 is likely to be a more challenging year for European general retailers with demand likely to soften. This is particularly likely in the UK, which remains the most important market for the sector. Retail stocks are typically early-cycle but there are risks a prolonged downturn means many could be value traps, particularly as the sector is typically showing average rather than extreme valuations. We like growth retailers and those with self-help, whilst we are a little wary of apparel retailers and find online stocks generally too expensive. Our top picks are AB Foods, B&M and Dixons Carphone, while we downgrade Next to Hold and Debenhams, Halfords and H&M to Sell.

PM11:18am

hmm

BE11:18am

There are two over-arching, and inescapable, themes for the retail sector in 2017. Firstly, we expect consumer demand to soften, especially in the UK where we forecast household discretionary spend growth to slow from 5.4% in 2016 to 4.2% in 2017, due to higher non-discretionary inflation. Secondly, cost of goods inflation should increase, though we think this can generally be handled without retailers feeling too much margin pain. The least-bad option is likely to be to raise prices. Some of the other interesting themes we examine are: the ongoing channel shift online; the prospect for value retailers; the potential for an apparel market recovery and the threat from Amazon Fashion; balance sheets and the major impact from future changes to lease accounting.

11:18 am
BE11:19am

Within the sector there are retailers with different rates of organic growth, levels of operational gearing and strength of balance sheet. Hence we should continue to see divergent share price performances. The sector has already de-rated, mainly on the changed demand and currency outlook due to Brexit, and valuations are typically at historical average levels – cheap but in some cases not cheap enough. The year has begun with virtually no consensus expectation for profit growth at the four FTSE100 UK retailers – Dixons Carphone, Kingfisher, M&S & Next – but this does not mean that EPS momentum will be positive or that stocks will re-rate in the year ahead. We look at what drove share prices in 2016 (generally more a change in multiple than EPS) and at the EV/Sales to EBIT margin rule-of-thumb to try and differentiate among retailers.

PM11:19am

Amazon Fashion? I'm behind the curve

BE11:20am

It exists, I think, though it mostly sells the kind of labels that turn up in the filler areas of TK Max.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Short term .............

BE11:20am

We highlight WH Smith as a potential Christmas winner. Reflecting our caution on apparel and impact of channel shift we downgrade Next to Hold, and both Debenhams and H&M to Sell. We also downgrade Halfords to Sell. Our valuation approach is usually DCF-based, except where multiple-based or SOTP approaches are more appropriate. Upside risks include consumer demand remaining robust for longer than we expect, improved currency rates, further cash distribution, or a re-rating in what is an early-cycle sector. Downside risks relate to the impact of a likely slowing of consumer demand as real incomes come under pressure from inflation and slowing employment growth. In addition, currency pressure is likely to trigger price rises (or margin contraction), with an uncertain volume impact.

BE11:21am

That's the first of the 99 pages. I'm a bit lost in terms of what detail to include, so here's a couple of the stock picks.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

One par each. Here's Next.

Next PLC (NXT:LSE): Last: 4,821, down 162 (-3.25%), High: 4,919, Low: 4,762, Volume: 357.93k
BE11:22am

Kantar data to mid November shows Next holding share in a tough market.
With homewares and international online supplementary to this we forecast
Brand full price LFL sales -0.2%, a substantial improvement on Q3’s -5.5%.
The company should also update on FY Jan-17 PBT expectations (DBe £800m),
initial budget for FY Jan-18 (DBe £780m PBT) and scope for buybacks (DBe
£350m) which should be higher due to lower capex and no further customer
credit book outflows. There is, however, still a risk that management gives
cautious guidance and holds back on buybacks

11:22 am
BE11:22am

Next update scheduled for tomorrow, right?

BE11:22am

Here's WH Smith.

WH Smith PLC (SMWH:LSE): Last: 1,562, up 4.21 (+0.27%), High: 1,579, Low: 1,549, Volume: 81.27k
11:23 am
BE11:23am

We have been long-term bulls of WH Smith and in mid-December we upgraded back to Buy. We think the Travel division growth platform is well established overseas and offers many years of growth. The High Street also has opportunities to grow profits because cost guidance looks conservative and because Post Office and Local offer potential growth. There is also a reasonable chance that the Cardmarket roll-out resumes in 2017. The stock trades on a CY17E FCF of around 7% with, we believe, less macro risk than most UK retailers. Buy.

BE11:23am

........ Carphone.

BE11:23am

Dixons Carphone looks well positioned for continued profit growth despite a challenging consumer backdrop and currency pressures. UK like for likes of +6% during Q2, shows both the gaining of market share and the sales transfer benefit from closing stores to reduce costs. Beyond the current FY Apr-17, which is boosted by merger synergies, there is c.£20m profit benefit from the property rationalization in FY Apr-18 and this should also be a year when Connected World Services, including the Sprint JV, should drive profit growth.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

.......... and M&S.

BE11:24am

The repositioning of Clothing has led to encouraging trends in market share, after four years of losses, and the rollout of Food-only stores continues to deliver attractive returns. However, the uncertain demand outlook, currency pressures on gross margins and more concerning underlying LFL trends in Food all present downside risks. International restructuring should eliminate losses but the slow pace of UK store restructuring is unlikely to deliver much benefit until 2019. Hold.
12th January: 3Q (Oct-Dec) expectations: UK LFL +0.1%
The Q3 calendar shift adds more high-value clearance Sale days at the end of December than in 2015. We expect +1% LFL sales in Clothing which would be its best performance since 3Q11. Whilst this still might seem disappointing in the context of a -11.6% 2-year comparative it would be an improvement from the H1 run rate. It assumes lower yoy promotion still a c.3% drag vs Sale timing a 2% boost. Food LFL of -0.5% should include a small (DBe +0.5%) boost from New Year’s Eve. Full-year Clothing GPM guidance of flat to +50bps (DBe +30bps) and UK opex +3.5% (DBe +3.3%) is likely to be maintained.

Dixons Carphone PLC (DC.:LSE): Last: 343.20, down 11.4 (-3.21%), High: 358.70, Low: 342.50, Volume: 1.34m
11:24 am
Marks and Spencer Group PLC (MKS:LSE): Last: 341.60, down 8.4 (-2.40%), High: 353.10, Low: 340.50, Volume: 2.83m
PM11:25am

Thanks for all that.

PM11:25am

We could usual place the Deutsche tome, but the usual place is shut -- till mid January, fingers crossed

11:25 am
BE11:25am

In that case, may as well do Halfords as well, since it's leading us down.

PM11:26am

Top of the Mid 250 fallers list

BE11:26am

Halfords’ ranges should prove relatively resilient in a soft UK consumer environment in 2017. However, weak Sterling has already begun to precipitate cautious comments on gross margins, whilst the company has relatively high operating leverage and is unlikely to have significant scope for cost-savings as it continues to build its customer- and service-centric capabilities. The acquisition of direct/ online specialists Tredz and Wheelies should accelerate digital development but not distract investors from core challenges. On 12.7x cal 2017E P/E Halfords shares trade on a premium to other mature UK retailers and with a similar FCF yield to higher-quality WH Smith (Buy; 1530p).

11:26 am
Halfords Group PLC (HFD:LSE): Last: 344.64, down 20.86 (-5.71%), High: 358.60, Low: 337.50, Volume: 592.71k
BE11:26am

Okay, so that's that.

BT - how they doing

PM11:27am

PM11:27am

11:27 am
PM11:28am

PM11:28am

PM11:28am

11:29 am

PM11:29am

PM11:29am

Oh dear. Hang on

11:29 am
PM11:30am

With huge apologies to Charles Dickens…

BE11:30am

........?

PM11:30am

Actually, this is from Dec 22, so we'll let em off

11:30 am
PM11:30am

With huge apologies to Charles Dickens…
Ebeneezer Scrooge had grown wealthy from the business of raising prices,
cutting costs and doing just enough on investment to maintain the creaking
network infrastructure on which the people increasingly depended. It was 7
years since the events of 2008/09 when a 25 quarter period of eps growth
came to a crashing end with the write-down of profits booked on expectations
of further efficiency gains. 7 years of growing dividends (re-based) has since
salved the memory of those darker times but Scrooge maintained his frugal
ways, ignoring pleas for more investment and longer-term thinking.
A visit from an old friend
One night, the regulator visited Scrooge as in a dream. Ebeneezer, I have been
watching you these last ten years since I relinquished control over your tariffs
and allowed supernatural returns on your superfast fibre. You need to mend
your ways else be forever cursed to wander the earth fully separated from your
physical form. Your poles and ducts will be festooned with the wires of your
competitors; your fibres will be lit only by the light from others, and your tariffs
to the poor, cut. You will be visited by three spirits. Listen to them.

PM11:30am

Didnt realise it was old

PM11:30am

The ghost of networks past
The first spirit took Ebeneezer to when his companies led the world in
technology and led alliances that spanned the globe. None of the budding
relationships stood the test of time however and Scrooge’s empire retreated to
its lucrative, isolated core. The regulator ensured competitors thrived but 2009
saw Scrooge take back control of prices and what others paid for fibre. Rollout
was swift and with no plans for further investment, returns moved higher.
The ghost of networks present
The second spirit took Scrooge to his networks of today – much less FTTH
than overseas, customers complaining, and Government and competitors alike
calling for investment in FTTH. Scrooge’s companies are diversified into mobile
and sports TV in order to control more of the population’s scarce coin.
Pensioners were left wondering how a yawning pension deficit would be
resolved, yet Scrooge’s adherence to parsimony was undiminished.
The ghost of networks future
The third spirit took Scrooge to visit his networks future: BT, a division of Telco
Energy; VODgin the largest UK provider of 1Gbps access, followed by SKYnet;
Openreach: struggling with copper after spending £££’s on pensions.
Humbug!
Will Ebeneezer awaken on Christmas morning with a willingness to invest in
the distant rather than near-term future? 2017 will tell all! We wish all our
readers a wonderful festive season and a peaceful and prosperous new year.

11:30 am
PM11:30am

That's enough pre-Xmas research

BE11:03am

The first Markets Live of 2017.

BE11:31am

Well yes, I'm not reading bloody Christmas Carol-themed equities research in January. I'd rather ont be reading it in December, yet analysts do insist on writing it.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

That and rewritings of the lyrics of "12 days of Christmas"

BE11:32am

Honestly, if I were ever unfortunate enough to work in research editing, I'd hunt down anyone who filed such a think and hit them with a plank. It's intolerable.

undefined
11:32 am
BE11:33am

In terms of more contemporaneous stuff .......

BE11:33am

........... we have Barclays pushing InterContinental.

InterContinental Hotels Group PLC (IHG:LSE): Last: 3,763, up 125 (+3.44%), High: 3,801, Low: 3,711, Volume: 501.39k
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Held off until it hit a record high, then upgraded.

BE11:34am

We upgrade to Overweight and raise our PT to 4000p. We see numerous reasons why EPS momentum can be positive in 2017 and we upgrade our 2017E EPS by 2.6% (see Figure 7), leaving us 3.5% ahead of Vuma consensus. Our 2018E EPS increases by 7%. We expect FY results on 21 Feb to be a positive catalyst. We also consider IHG to be the best play in the sector on a potential rebound in US growth (key lead indicator looks encouraging) as well as potential tax cuts. Our upgrade misses the first 10% increase, but our £40 PT suggests 12% upside potential and our upside case of £46 suggests 28% potential upside in 2017. IHG now becomes our preferred hotel pick, followed by Accor (OW, €38 PT). Whitbread (UW, 3440p PT) remains our least preferred (though as we discussed in RevPAR weekly (22/12/16), we see some short-term upside there too).

BE11:35am

We noted a few times in the run-up to Christmas, at least in the paper, that UK RevPar was surprisingly strong.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Led by London, which was doing double digits.

BE11:36am

Don't entirely know why. Is it a sterling thing?

PM11:36am

Guess so -- lots of tourists

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Catalyst: As we discussed in Feedback from meeting with CFO (23/11/2016), we think FY results can be a positive catalyst for four reasons: 1) Cash Return Announcement – we expect IHG to announce a c$350m return (c4% annualised EPS boost), which would take leverage up to c2.4x ND/EBITDA. While we have had numerous cash return announcements in previous years, we would view this one as particularly significant since it would be unrelated to one-off asset sales and instead reflect the underlying cash generative business model. This could be the start of an annual process of significant cash returns (as we see from US peers). 2) Margins – we think FY guidance of c120bps margin growth vs. 290bps in H1 is conservative and we see upside risk. 3) Q4 RevPAR beat – RevPAR growth in the US upper midscale segment is tracking at 3.6% in Q4 vs. 1.8% in Q3. We raise our FY forecasts to reflect stronger US RevPAR. 4) Net system growth – while we do not envisage a positive surprise in Q4 (management previously flagged Q4 will look soft in light of comps), we do expect more positive commentary regarding the net system growth outlook and raise our 2017 forecast to 3.9% from 3.5% and 2018 to 4.4% from 3.6%.

BE11:37am

Valuation: While 18.7x cal17E PE appears high, IHG has one of the strongest EPS CAGRs in our coverage at 15% with the highest ROCE at 57%. Multiples are sensitive to the US RevPAR cycle, but we feel more constructive here, too. Furthermore, we see numerous sources of potential upside risk to forecasts. Our upside case of £46 assumes 1) 2.5% stronger RevPAR growth p/a, 2) 120bps margin expansion p/a, 3) US corp tax rate cut to 15% (gives a 6% reduction to IHG’s group tax rate) and 4) annual cash returns to retain 2.5x ND/EBITDA.

BE11:38am

Just trying to find the RevPar data from the past few weeks of 2016, since I mentioned it ......

11:38 am
BE11:39am

............ Bingo.

BE11:39am

US RevPAR grew 5.9% in November improving from +1.6% in October and
+5.6% in September. Trailing 12-month RevPAR was +3.3% in November
compared to +3.2% in October and +3.6% in September. The two-year growth
rate was 10.3% in November, improving from +8.1% in October but down from a
strong +13.6% in September. Room rates grew 3.4% in November versus +1.9% in
October and +3.9% in September. Occupancy increased by 2.5% in November
compared to -0.3% in October and +1.6% in September. US RevPAR is now c.24%
above its 2008 peak on a TTM basis (in nominal terms). 3Q RevPAR was up 3.4%
for the industry. RevPAR for the week ending 10th December was up 5.7%. IHG
reported 1.4% RevPAR growth in the US for Q3, weaker than the 1.9% seen in the
US upper midscale segment in which it operates (here). Hilton and Marriott also
reported weaker RevPAR growth in Q3 than previously guided, and they guide to
1-3% and 0-2% respectively. Our US team forecasts +1.7% RevPAR growth for
2017 and relatively flat growth for 2018

BE11:39am

UK RevPAR up 7.0% in November from a decline of 4.6% in October and growth
of 1.2% in September. The two-year growth rate improved to 7.0% from +3.1%
and +6.6% in October and September. TTM RevPAR was +0.8% in November vs.
+0.2% in October and +1.4% in September. Occupancy was up 3.5% in November
(vs. -2.0% in October), and room rates were up 3.3% (vs. -2.6% in October). Within
the mix, London RevPAR grew by 8.0% in November compared to -11.1% in
October and +0.7% in September, driven by increase in both room rates and
occupancy by 2.6% and 5.31% respectively. UK Regional RevPAR grew 6.3% in
November from +0.9% in October and +1.7% in September, with 2.9% room rate
growth and 3.4% occupancy growth.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

That's Morgan Stanley, and sorry for the lumpy formatting.

BE11:41am

It's easier to see in graph form.

BE11:41am

11:40 am

11:41 am
PM11:42am

BE11:42am

BE11:43am

11:43 am
BE11:43am

(@jimpj: I can't remember a week in the past two years when that hasn't been a rumour.)

BE11:44am

Martin Beck, senior economic advisor to the EY ITEM Club, wins the prize for "first email I've found after typing "manufacturing PMI"

BE11:44am

So here's his thoughts.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

“Having softened a touch in November, December’s manufacturing PMI more than made up for the previous month’s dip, with the index increasing from 53.6 to 56.1. This was well above the long-run average of 51.5 and represented the strongest reading since June 2014. It also left the PMI for the fourth quarter as a whole at a two-and-a-half year high.

“Domestic demand appears to be holding up well, while the survey’s measure of export orders also increased for the seventh successive month, aided by the weaker pound. However, sterling’s depreciation continued to translate into relatively rapid increases in input prices. Meanwhile, December’s survey pointed to the production of investment and intermediate goods expanding at a faster pace than consumer goods, offering some reassurance in light of fears that Brexit-related uncertainty will sap business investment.

“On the basis of past form, the manufacturing PMI points to output expanding close to 1% in Q4. However, while official data for the quarter is currently only available for October, that output fell by 1% in that month which means that the sector will struggle to emulate the survey’s buoyant picture. Looking forward, 2017 is likely to see a slowdown in domestic demand as higher inflation bites. But a likely continuation of sterling’s weakness and a stronger global outlook offers some cause for optimism among ‘the makers’.”

BE11:44am

Thumbs up

BE11:45am

Possibly more important was China PMI, though it'd doing very little either for miners or metals prices.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

China – Manufacturing sector posted the strongest performance since Jan/13 in Dec/16 with “a sustained increase” in new orders.

New business growth was at its strongest since Jul/14 driven by improved local demand with new export sales unchanged last month.
Inflation climbed to the highest level since early 2011 on the back of an increase in raw input costs.
Caixin Manufacturing PMI: 51.9 v 50.9 in Nov and 50.9 forecast.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 285.15, up 7.8 (+2.81%), High: 286.20, Low: 279.40, Volume: 14.72m
Antofagasta PLC (ANTO:LSE): Last: 688.50, up 13.5 (+2.00%), High: 690.50, Low: 678.00, Volume: 1.31m

BE11:49am

However, we mentioned the speculation here: https://www.ft.com...-9043-7e34c07b46ef ... and mention it again now, if only as a reminder.

undefined
11:49 am
PM11:49am

We havent mentioned this, which was all over the radio this morning

PM11:49am

http://www.telegra...mc_id=tmg_share_tw

PM11:50am

Britain will become a “beacon of global free trade” and create nearly 400,000 new jobs if it quits the customs union as part of the Brexit negotiations, it has been suggested.

An analysis by Change Britain, a group with the backing of Michael Gove, said that leaving the European Union’s customs union and striking trade agreements with just eight foreign countries will create hundreds of thousands of jobs in manufacturing and service industries.

11:49 am
PM11:50am

Really?

PM11:50am

A chance to re-share this, which is mesmerising

PM11:50am
11:50 am
PM11:51am

Michael Gove's human suit malfunctioned

BE11:51am

Hm. It's been an odd year for Mr Gove.

BE11:52am

The fact that the Telegraph chose -- apropos of apparently nothing -- to illustrate that story with him in doing a Right Said Fred picture does hint at his current career trajectory.

11:52 am
BE11:52am

Six months ago he could have been prime minister. Now he's this year's Lembit Öpik. Politics is harsh.

undefined
BE11:53am

I guess we can pick through the news for this remaining eight minutes.

11:53 am
BE11:53am

Britvic's bought something.

BE11:53am

Bela Ischia Alimentos

BE11:54am

Second Brazilian acquisition. £54.5m

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Geography seems to be the point, rather than brand expansion.

BE11:54am

Morgan Stanley can explain.

BE11:55am

This follows the acquisition by Britvic of another Brazilian soft drinks business Ebba in summer 2015 (the acquisition price of Ebba was BRL 580m, 12.1x EBITDA). The Bela Ischia brands have a similar consumer proposition to Ebba brands but different geographic footprint; the Bela Ischia brands are the leaders in juice/concentrates Rio De Janeiro, whilst Ebba brands Maguary and Dafruta are more popular in Sao Paulo and the North East respectively. Bela Ischia top line grew by double digits in the last 12 months, reaching BRL 160m of sales and BRL 18.5m of EBITDA. The acquisition represents Britvic doubling-down on their commitment to Brazil, where their existing business saw strong revenue growth in FY16 (+19%).

11:55 am
BE11:55am

"Substantial annual cost synergies" are a key aspect of the deal. Whilst Britvic have not quantified the benefit of these synergies in this morning's press release we expect synergies in procurement, logistics and production. The company expects the deal to complete by the end of March and to be EPS accretive in the first full year (low single digit in our view, though this has not been quantified by the company). When Britvic acquired Ebba in 2015 they issued guidance to double EBITDA by 2020, and deliver sustainable cost savings of BRL $10m in the short term.

BE11:55am

The c.£54.5m acquisition will be funded through existing debt facilities, and will take Britvic's net debt to EBITDA up to 2.3x in FY17e, based on our numbers. Whilst cashflow remains weak as Brtivic continues to spend on incremental capex in GB, this level of leverage remains manageable, in our view.

BE11:55am

Britvic is the cheapest stock in our coverage universe on a P/E basis at 11.4x CY18 EPS. It offers an attractive 4.4% CY18 dividend yield, although FCF yield remains low in light of incremental capex spending.

11:55 am
Britvic PLC (BVIC:LSE): Last: 572.00, up 5 (+0.88%), High: 579.00, Low: 569.00, Volume: 362.13k
BE11:56am

.... And we've got Boohoo buying something as well.

Founded by Sophia Amoruso in 2006, Nasty Gal is a bold and distinctive online forward fashion brand for young women. The business is US-centric but services a limited number of key international geographies; the brand mix is centred on the Nasty Gal own brand and also includes a number of relevant and complementary third-party forward fashion brands. Nasty Gal has two physical outlets in Los Angeles in addition to the online presence.

Rewinding on Nasty Gal -- the business went bust in the autumn

PM12:00pm

Sophia Christina Amoruso (born April 20, 1984)[1] is an American businesswoman. At 22, Amoruso started an online eBay store selling vintage clothing and other items, which she named "Nasty Gal Vintage."

Based on the success of her online store, Amoruso founded Nasty Gal, a women's fashion retailer, which went on to be named one of "the fastest growing companies" by Inc. Magazine in 2012.[2] In 2016, she was named one of the richest self-made women in the world by Forbes.[3]

On November 9, 2016 Nasty Gal filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings.

BE12:00pm

Nasty Gal printed revenue of US$77.1m in the year ended 1 February 2016, including revenue from third-party brands, that are excluded from the proposed transaction. Nasty Gal made a net loss after tax of US$21.0m. And to be clear, the proposed transaction relates to the acquisition of intellectual property assets only and excludes all operating costs. The rationale for BOO. BOO's US business is nascent, but growing rapidly, H117 £15.2m revenue, +93% YoY and appears to be capturing the imagination of US domiciled forward fashion conscious, young consumers. The addition of the Nasty Gal brand and the customer databases, BOO believe, would complement their existing brand portfolio and allow BOO to leverage existing product development, supply and distribution functions to accelerate international growth, particularly in the US, building on BOO’s existing customer reach and product range.

BE12:01pm

What do we think? We have enjoyed BOO's broader thinking around brand, the extension into Boohoo Kids etc, the addition of the PLT brand and view the Nasty Gal brand as a positive addition to drive BOO harder and faster into the still, remarkably early stage online US forward fashion opportunity.
In terms of consideration, it seems likely that the experience gained in valuing the PLT business will have informed BOO's bid and whilst clearly opportunistic given Nasty Gal's Chapter 11, the brand is complementary, is very much US centric and should BOO be successful through the auction process, the opportunity to accelerate the US business, in particular, we would view as a distinct positive.
That said, something of a first for the Group, the US BOO business has gained real momentum, but incorporating the Nasty Gal brand and customer assets will bring some operational challenge. However, given the operational performance of the senior management team over the last 18 months, the opportunity here seems too good to miss.

As a young adult, Amoruso lived a nomadic lifestyle, hitchhiking on the west coast, dumpster diving, and stealing.[9] In 2003, while living in Portland, Oregon, Amoruso was caught stealing; the loss-prevention of the store fined Amoruso, and the experience led her to stop stealing.[9] Amoruso left Portland and relocated to San Francisco, shortly after which she discovering she had a hernia in her groin, which necessitated her purchasing health insurance for required medical treatments.[8] While attending community college, Amoruso worked in a school lobby checking student IDs.
